segments.text: This is an interview with Dr. J. George H. Thompson, professor emeritus of mechanical engineering at Texas A&M.
Today's date is November 5th, 1981.
Let's begin, Dr. Thompson, by you telling us something about your early years.
Where and when were you born, and what we hear growing up your life.
How do I speak?
Well, just leave it there.
Stop my fussing.
I was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, April 11, 1911, 70 years ago.
I had a very happy childhood as I'm having a very happy retirement.
I was brought up in an industrial city.
I spent most of my time in shops when I wasn't in school.
I worked in every sort of shop around the city.
I worked in a drawing room.
I worked in a machine shop.
I worked in a foundry.
And I became somewhat skilled in use of my hands in all the various shops.
I worked in a tin shop.
I took a mechanical arts course in high school and also a college preparatory course, a double course in high school.
I then went to Penn State where I got a baccalaureate degree in mechanical engineering in June of 1933.
Tell us about your father.
What was his occupation?
My father was a foundryman.
He was the part owner and manager of a cast iron foundry.
And in later years, he developed the business to include iron, aluminum, brass, bronze, and all sorts of metals.
He would take a job, a large job, and he would break it up and give each foundry and each shop that portion it could do well and deliver the finished product, whatever it be, to the customer.
Sometimes a series of castings, sometimes machine parts, sometimes assembled machines.
And he had some 50 years experience in the Philadelphia region as a foundry.
And I grew to learn and love machinery as a result of my contact with my father and all the people with whom he dealt.
About six years old, I knew I was either going to be a preacher or a teacher.
and I loved machinery.
So I decided to take mechanical engineering, learn machine design, which I've taught ever since, and I have never regretted the choice.
I knew I'd better be a teacher instead of a preacher because I think I'd gotten kicked out of the churches because I have a sense of humor that's a little flippant for a preacher.
But it's been a good life, and I found at A&M

a rewarding experience in which you feel that you seriously have contributed and you can respect and at the same time I found no end of love on the part of my colleagues and my superiors and my students and it's been a great life, period.
Tell us about when you went to Penn State in 1933.
I went in 1929, was graduated in 33.
Now let's see, what sort of things would you like to know about Penn State?
What kind of school it was?
It was a wonderful school.
We had about 4,000 students at the time.
It was in what might be called a crude stage.
All the streets did not have lights.
There were only four lighted blocks in the whole city and the campus combined.
And in my freshman year, if you went out after dark, you had to carry a flashlight because that's the only way you could tell whether you're going to walk into a ditch.
Those were the old sort of primitive days.
Penn State is way up in the mountains, and it is now a 40,000 campus, very sophisticated.
But in 1929, it was very primitive.
What city is it in?
It's in its own city of college, State College, Pennsylvania.
And the name has been changed to College Park, Pennsylvania since.
Both names are still used.
It's 38 miles from the nearest railroad station.
And on cold days when the snow was heavy, people couldn't get over the mountain from the trains.
And we would sometimes be isolated for a couple of days.
We had a very wonderful faculty.
We had an excellent college of engineering, and it was a very rich experience.
I was a fraternity man, and I was very active in student affairs.
I was vice president of the Penn State Christian Association in my senior year.
And I feel that we had a very, very rich four years of student activities and academic instruction.
How were you affected by the Depression?
We were completely wiped out.
My father's business went bankrupt.
The bank in which we had our life savings went bankrupt, and the building alone in which we had a nest egg went bankrupt.
Daddy had $50,000 saved up, and the idea was that I was to go to Germany and get a master's or maybe a doctorate degree.
We had the money in the bank.
And in a matter of a couple of weeks, we lost every penny we had, including that.
So I was transformed from the son of someone who had prepared financially for his son to someone who had no money.
For some time each morning, Father and I would put a new piece of cardboard in our shoes because we had a hole in the soles and we couldn't afford to have them repaired.

Later on we found that Woolworth had a little 10 cent kit with a little rubber sole and a little scraper and a little tube of cement and we'd put those on our shoes because we couldn't afford to take them to the shoemaker.
Daddy couldn't afford a medical doctor so for a while he would go to a free clinic in the city.
All of his business companions, I believe, went legally bankrupt.
My father would not.
He spent about 11 years paying his debts and finally paid everyone off.
So the bank
The depression hit us very hard financially, but it did not affect us spiritually.
I think our family was as strong and probably as happy after the loss as before.
The money really didn't matter that much.
I went back to my senior year in college with a total of $11 cash.
I got a job waiting tables, and I got no money for that, but I got all the food I could eat.
And I got odd jobs doing carpentry work.
and helping professors put on their storm doors for the winter and earn enough money that way to take care of my other needs, I borrowed $300 from a foundation to take care of my tuition and books.
And I had a very lean senior year financially, but a very rich senior year in all other ways.
So the Depression wasn't all bad for us.
Did your father finally recover from the financial loss?
He recovered, but he never again had any money ahead as he had had before.
He recovered in the sense that he paid all his bills, and he earned enough money to pay his own way.
And so he could take care of himself, but he never again was able to collect the kinds of money he had collected before.
What year did he die?
He was 85.
I was very sickly as a child, barely surviving childbirth.
And at approximately age 20, I seemed to take a turn, and I have grown much stronger ever since.
And at the present time, I would say I'm in excellent health.
What about your mother?
What did she do to help the family during the Depression?
She was a loving mother and wife and a good housewife.
And she gave both father and myself great strength, wisdom, and support.
After you completed a degree at Penn State in 1933, what did you do then?
I worked for six months building a machine myself, there being no jobs available.
Several machine shops in Philadelphia permitted me to use their facilities.
And I made a machine which I gave to the college.
And shortly thereafter, the college recommended me for a job.
And in January of 1934, I went to work in Ludlow, Massachusetts.
L-U-D-L-O-W.
It's next to Springfield in southwestern Massachusetts.
And I was a design engineer there for approximately four years.
I designed all sorts of machinery, some for local and some for international use.
At the end of that period, I got a professional degree of mechanical engineering from Penn State based on my experience, and I came down to Texas A&M in September 1938 to teach machine design.
In later years, I got first the master's and then the Ph.D. from Texas A&M.
I'm a registered professional engineer in the state of Texas, and I'm doing consulting for a major corporation today.
When did you get the advanced degrees?
I got the master's in 1950 and the doctorate in 1962.
What was the subject of your dissertation research?
A three-dimensional photoelastic study involving photoelasticity and computer analysis.
It involved beam-on-elastic foundation theory and some other topics that perhaps are more technical than you need to worry about now.
You've been at A&M since 1938.
This is my 44th year teaching at A&M.
How did you happen to decide to come here all the way from Massachusetts?
I wanted very much to get into teaching because I knew I wanted that for life work.
I was engaged, but I wanted my job before I got married.
I wrote between 90 and 100 letters of application.
This was another, in 1938, was another recession of some severity.
Of the 90 to 100 letters of application, I received only one favorable answer.
That was from Texas A&M.
So I came here knowing nothing about the school, simply because it was the only place that had a job.
Other colleges were letting professors go.
We were mushrooming and ever since we have had prosperity at A&M to much greater measure than many, many colleges in the country.
I think the two most important things in my life were coming to A&M and getting married.
When did you get married?
I got married in June of 1939.
What about your wife's background?
She came from Ludlow, Massachusetts where her father was town attorney and had other offices in the town and was very active in all the life of that town.
She come from a family very active in the church work of the town.
And I met her partly through Sunday school activity.
And being a small town, we were thrown together quite a bit.
Does she regret moving all the way from Massachusetts?
Oh, no.
She fell in love with Texas.
And she especially liked the friendliness of the people here in Texas.
as a Yankee yourself, and you found the Texans are friendly?
Yes, but I wasn't a Yankee at the first.
I'm a Yankee almost now.

A little while ago, I was a damn Yankee, but when I first came here, there were two words before the Yankee, and I found that the people here are friendly, are friendly deep inside, and I never want to leave this part of the country.
OK, what about your teaching career over all this time?
Would you elaborate a little more on that?
I would say that I'm a teacher who loves a subject, in my case, machine design, and who loves each student equally well.
And I have loved the teaching.
It's been a very rewarding experience.
And I practically never find myself in a big city airport on a trip but that I come across a former student.
And the former students are simply wonderful.
I think I love them, and they love me, and I think I have reached some students in a modest way.
I love them.
They're wonderful people, and to share my life with these fine people has been a very wonderful life.
Period.
You've taught machine design all through this time.
Yes, sir.
I have taught many other courses, but my main course is machine design.
I do a marvelous job.
When did you become a full professor?
That I cannot...

tell you I don't remember but I can find no I don't I just don't remember oh goodness gracious this was I'd say 20 or 30 years ago no yeah I did when I was younger and now I'm glad I didn't because I think I'm happiest although I had a touch of administration in
In the years that I had, for six or seven years, I had a three-month summer program sponsored by the National Science Foundation for talented secondary students.
And then the college chose to name me the director of the All-University Honors Program.
And I occupied that post for six or seven years until I retired in August of 77.
And that was very rewarding.
And to some little extent, that was administrative.
At one time, I thought of such things as department heads and deans.
Now I'm very happy that it's worked out the way it is.
I've been able to meet more wonderful students, and I've had the time to work with the students.
And I'm very grateful for the way things have worked out.
What are some of the changes that you've seen on this campus over this 40-something year period?

I think I see a change not on this campus alone but nationally from a primary emphasis on teaching of undergraduate individuals to a primary emphasis on scientific recognition on the part of the professors.
This is national, not just A&M.
I think at A&M I find an increasing
The excellence of equipment, of facilities, far better academic training of the professors than we used to have.
I think we probably are doing our best technical job today.
The teachers are better equipped than they used to be academically.
They have better tools to work with.
They've had more training before they started teaching.
I would say that A&M is becoming a very creditable institution, honored internationally, whereas 50 years ago we were known in Texas, but people did not take us seriously out of Texas.
Have you mostly concentrated on teaching or what about your research activities?
I've had seven years full time in industry doing machine design in addition to my teaching.
I have done very little research because my field happens to be machine design where the end product is to make a piece of hardware that works.
And my consulting at the present time is in that field.
where rather than write a paper about something, I actually build something that works.
In my opinion, it's no more worthy and no less worthy than the writing of papers.
But it's a characteristic of my kind of engineering that you devote your attention to creating, building, and perfecting a total machine.
engineering college began to devote so much attention to research and what caused this to occur?
I think, did you say engineering colleges or our engineering college?
Both.
Okay.
Colleges in general, colleges like MIT, Harvard, Princeton, University of Pennsylvania,
always put engineering research on a very, very high priority level.
A&M evidently now seeks to become recognized as what we call a first-class university, whatever that means.
I'm not sure what that means.
And such universities all put the publication of scholarly paper or important practical work

on a high level in engineering or whatever the subject as increasingly important and this is good it's not all bad and this took this came about gradually I would say since World War II we have seen it accelerate and at the present time the general feeling is that we ought to become
expert in our field of knowledge on a higher technical level than before.
This is a blending of our thoughts with the international trends all over the world.
Now the reason for this is that when you design a 747 aircraft, the consequences of failure are exceedingly serious.
Fifty years ago, we just didn't design equipment that would hurt many people
if it broke down.
Today we design much equipment that would kill people if it breaks down.
So we're having, all over the world, we're having to be more careful since we're going to higher pressures, higher temperatures, and higher speeds.
It's that simple.
What changes have you seen in the
engineering program at A&M with the enrollment of women in the program?
The women are increasing the academic quality of the program in most cases.
They do their homework more regularly.
They study harder.
They make better grades.
So I would say that the women, who I feel are a most wholesome and praiseworthy group,
are contributing in increasing the academic quality of the teaching of the student work at A&M.
The biggest liability these girls suffer is their
inability to visualize spatially and their inability to visualize hardware.
This does not in any way suggest that the women aren't smart.
It simply says that when they were playing with dolls, boys were fixing their cars.
And so the boys have heard what a wrench is, what a spanner is.
It's a wrench.
what a gear is, what a bearing is, what spark advance means.
And the little girls at the same age never had an opportunity to learn those things.
So when we get into serious engineering problems, you have to explain and draw pictures of many, many machine elements with which the girls are not familiar and the boys are.
So I would say that the girls are wholesome.
They have every quality that the boys have ability-wise, but that their background has not provided them with as ample a knowledge of current hardware and conventional terms.
What about the black steelers?
Are there any black steelers in engineering?
And if so, why?
I think that A&M has been particularly forward in being fair to the black students.
We don't have time to go into many specific cases, but I feel that I'm proud of A&M's part in that.
I've had black students in class.
I had a delightful conversation with one who now is with General Electric and doing a fine job.
And I've had some excellent ones up to whom I have not been able to give equally high grades.
The thing holding them back now is not in any way any attitude or performance at A&M but simply that usually they come with an inferior background from their previous schools.
They simply do not know their algebra as well as our people do and in graduate work in particular
they haven't had the opportunity to have equal education.

Now, as a people, they're just as capable as we are, and when we give them equal education, as is taking place today, more every day, they will excel and we'll have just as many black people succeed as white people.
There's no question about that.
It's simply a question that
Many of them went through a period of their life where they didn't get as good education as the white people living in the same town.
I'm proud of A&M.
I think A&M has been more than fair.
I don't want to go to too many cases, but I remember one case of a black boy who acted strangely.
And I finally had pinned him down.
And it seemed that Pytos Sigma had not taken him in.
And he felt he was discriminated against.
We found it had nothing to do with his color, but he had come from Lamar, and somehow the big computer had not credited him with the credit hours he transferred from Lamar.
This happens every now and then, black or white.
And so on the eligibility list, his name never appeared.
The instant I pointed this out to the Pythos Sigma officers, they held a special meeting, they elected in membership, and they initiated him within, I think, a week or so later.
And so we can cite many cases.
I'm proud of A&M.
I think we have welcomed the black people, not because they're black, but just because they're people.
And I think we have been very fair.
I'm real proud of the way we're going.
I think as soon as these people get the training necessary, that they'll find in A&M a place to do serious work without any regard to race.
Are you involved in teaching graduates and undergraduates?
No longer.
Since the day I retired, I was removed from the graduate faculty.
Because after 65, you're senile and you no longer are capable of such advanced work.
I have had Ph.D. students and master's students in my earlier years, and some of them are doing beautifully today.
Well, you're younger than the present.
Sure, sure.
Would you recommend that a bachelor's degree holder in mechanical engineering pursue graduate studies today if their goal were to work in the industry, or would you recommend that they just work?
I think it would be inappropriate to make a blanket statement.
That's something like, do people like apple pie?
Some people do, some do not.
Now, specifically, if they go with Westinghouse, say, Westinghouse would rather have them not have even a master's.
They'd like to have them go and get a baccalaureate degree only.
And then I'm thinking the South Philadelphia works.
And then spend about a semester or so getting their place in the company.
Then the company will help them financially and in other ways to blend a master's program into their work at Westinghouse.
This way, the company can afford to very substantially assist them.
And they, in turn, can take courses so their master's program they take at, say, University of Pennsylvania at night
will tie in with the work they're doing a day at the plant.
And they'll come out with a very rich master's program.
There are a number of companies who like to do that.
They like to have them integrate their master's program with the work at the plant.

Westinghouse in Pittsburgh and other companies I know of also will substantially contribute to the PhD program if you will integrate it so there's a possibility that you might bring your PhD training back to the company later.
And they expect that a few will come and many won't come.
But I'd say that it depends on the individual case.
I know a company in Houston that doesn't want you unless you have a PhD.
And I know other companies that can't use you as well unless you have only the baccalaureate.
They'd like to have a hand in your training.
How do you think the mechanical engineering program at A&M compares with such programs at other universities?
Well, there again, you've asked in a short interview a 20-hour discussion, because every college is quite different.
I would say that the master's program at A&M, as it was when I retired when I was acquainted with it, was quite a superior program and represented one of the better schools.
I would say that as of the day I retired that our PhD program
did not have the faculty, the equipment, or the ongoing research to be as rewarding to the student as MIT or Stanford.
I think that we are growing, and with the passage of time, I think we will grow into being a very fine graduate school in engineering.
MIT and Stanford and certain of those schools have a little advantage in that they have millions and millions of dollars of equipment, staff, and ongoing research.
And I believe that we are going to be just as good as those schools in time.
Could you discuss any changes in the
Oh, yes, yes.
The students know more book learning today than they did 40 years ago.
The students do not possess the common sense nor the personal resourcefulness that their predecessors knew.
Now, this is simple.
40, 50 years ago, a boy in Texas had to be careful to not be bitten by a rattlesnake.
If he lived in West Texas, he had many adventures in his daily life that involved danger.
Today, we're getting concrete roads everywhere.
We're having policemen everywhere.
I remember when there were no policemen in College Station.
I went to the district judge to ask him what to do, and he said, get a Colt 38.
And that's a little different than the attitude today.
So in the old days, from childhood, a boy in Texas learned to rely upon his wits and keep his eyes open against danger.
Today we're becoming more cultured, more civilized, subject to many, many more rules and regulations.
People look out for us more.
High schools today look out for the kids a lot more than they did 40 years ago.
That means that the kids are getting better academic training, but they're not as resourceful, they're not as tough in themselves because they don't have to fend for themselves quite as much.
These people today will be just as successful as their predecessors, but they're going to get their capabilities in a different sequence.
They're going to get their jolts after college.
The other kids had quite a few jolts before they came.
Has there been any period of time, any particular year, that the quality of the students that you were involved with was superior to those above all of the others?
Oh, yes.
The first couple of groups of combat veterans who came back
were tough, eager, worked very hard.
I remember one boy in particular who had flown a hundred combat missions.
He would sit on the front row, McGuire was his last name, and he would listen.
I never saw him take a note.
And I believe two months later he could recite word for word everything I said.
He wouldn't have been able to survive 100 combat missions if he hadn't developed the capacity for tremendous observation and memory.
And he remembered the dangers and was attentive to them.
And in class, he made A every time.
Because those first groups after the combat, they and some who didn't come back paid heavily for their learning.
The only way they got back alive was to become alert.
And when they come back, they were mature, they were alert, and they were aware that they lost a couple of years.
They were great.
They were great.
They weren't any better individuals than students today, but the students today haven't had such a painful price to pay to get maturity fast.
Have there been any specific instances that you can cite in other cases in which students on an individual basis show great talent or resourcefulness that you
Oh, yes.
I don't want to have to pull names out of the hat today.
Toppy Pierce was one, but we have had a number of cases of extremely brilliant students.
Carl, oh, fudge, Carl, oh, I can't think of his last name now.
Oh, he's now just doing tremendously with General Dynamics in Fort Worth.
He is in charge of all automatic controls on the modern airplanes in Fort Worth.
He's got a tremendous job.
He got a recognition as the outstanding master's student when I was his master's chairman, and later he won a prize as the outstanding doctoral student at Texas A&M.
And Carl has justified that.
He has gone right up the ladder, and he's making major contributions today.
Yes, I don't know whether I've answered your question.
I haven't given you enough details, but we have had some very, very unusual students and students who have contributed much to their profession.
Have there been any that you've been associated with who overcame great handicaps from poor family backgrounds and so forth?
Yes, there was a black boy, and I'm not going to mention his name.
I think it would be improper.

Because of his race and because of the low income level of his family and the kind of clothes he wore, he was arrested going through one of our modern cities, one of our big cities in Texas, simply because he looked out of place in the nice neighborhood.
And this was an improper action on the part of the police, I believe, the way they arrested him.
But nevertheless, he came to A&M with a chip on his shoulder.
And he was clearly of a minority.
He had much against him, mental attitude, everything.
And we worked on that boy.
And we challenged him.
I remember several ways we challenged him.
We turned him around.
And he became impressed with our set of values.
He's with a major corporation today.
He has a nice family.
He's going right up the ladder.
He's a complete success.
He overcome not only the lack of money, the lack of social graces, but he overcome his bad attitudes.
And I'm proud again, I'm very proud of A&M.
This was one of many boys that A&M turned around because we have given many students a good, what I'm proud to call, American set of values.
They raise good families, they're good clean living people, and they contribute much to the world about them.
I remember another boy that came back with lost an arm at Okinawa.
This isn't what you asked me, but it's another case.
And I remember that boy very well.
He had every reason to be a handicap.
And what happened there, it was critical that he not whine or complain.
And we got another student who had lost the same arm in Austria and got them in a room together.

And I couldn't speak to the boy who lost his arm because I didn't lose my arm, but the other boy who lost his arm could, and I could hear through the door some unprintable words, well, you so-and-so, don't you have guts enough to take care of your problems?
And that changed this boy's life, and this happened at A&M.
And the boy who was just wavering decided he better be a man.
I graded him just as harshly for four drawings as if he'd had two arms.
I didn't relent a bit.
And so he got toughened up to face the world as it was, as he was.
And he went into industry and was a good success.
A&M has contributed so much that's wholesome and good to many people.
I hope we keep that strength that's A&M.
And I think we have a greater measure of that strength in many, many schools.
What about the rivalry between the University of Texas at Austin and A&M?
What do you have to comment about that?
Yes, I think I have a delightful true story on that.
I had a small part in the forming of a society here called Pito Sigma, a branch of a National Honor Society.
And I told our boys who were interested in forming our society that I was going over to Austin to see if their chapter would help us get started.
And I remember vividly one of our boys said, well, sir, don't drive over there with a college station license plate.
They'll throw bricks at you, which was so silly.
In other words, our undergraduates really had a rivalry that was almost unwholesome.

I went over there, and the first thing their boys said when I said what I was there for, one boy raised his hand and was recognized by the chair and said, Sir, I wish that we would make it unanimous to support Texas A&M.
The Aggies are very fine people, and I, for one, would be proud to have them in our honor society.
And they even went so far as to elect all our candidates, so if we didn't get our charter, they would elect them.
Through their group, they would elect them into Paito Sigma.
And the University of Texas at Austin staff and student body alike just went out of their way to help us.
Now, our students didn't understand it at the time, but I think later when they reflected on it, they found that there is a normal, wholesome rivalry which I hope never subsides.
But beyond that, there is a camaraderie that says we are all one.
What are some of your observations about the rapid growth of the university in the last 43 years?
When did this growth start?
This started as far as I was concerned in 1938 because the reason I got my job here was that when other colleges over the nation were actually letting professors go because they're
Their enrollment had dwindled.
We had so many new students here that we took on seven new instructors in mechanical engineering alone in September of 1938.
We were mushrooming.
We were a very small school then, but we were rapidly increasing.
And I suspect that we have grown more rapidly than many other colleges.
We just never seemed to stop.
Of course, there was a time in World War II when they just took practically every boy on the campus into the Army.
Pardon me, but that's not an ordinary circumstance.
I don't really know why we have such an increase in enrollment.
It may be that so many people of high caliber are moving down here to the Sun Belt that their children want to go to college.
It may be, and it could well be, that they respect what students get here.
I don't know that.
I really think, even though I'm one of the staff, that we give a more rigorous course here than many engineering colleges.
And I do know that many companies pay more for an Aggie than they would for many other schools.
And I also know that it's harder to get great points here than at some of the other schools.
I would say that Rice, Austin, and A&M are each an excellent school, each has a slightly different end desire, and that all three are worthy of greatest respect.
I have been too far removed from that level of activity to make any intelligent comment.
I'm not trying to get out of commenting.
It's just that that's rather far removed from a classroom teacher.
Do you have any other amusing stories to tell about former students or instances that have occurred here over this long period of time?
Well, I guess it was amusing.
Yes, I guess we could have several.
I think I'd better not get these down on tape, but there were some funny things, including the time when we all came in 1938.
Professor Berryman and I each had one suit with two pair of pants.
We were poor then, very poor.
He had his one pair of pants and his coat and vest in at the cleaner.
He was in taking a shower, so I hid his only other pair of pants under his mattress.
And I come to class and forgot.
So Professor Berryman couldn't find his pants, so he called the department to tell the secretary that he couldn't come to class because he couldn't find his pants.
And she being a girl, he was embarrassed and hung up.
So he called a few minutes later, and Professor Crawford, who was then head of the department...
immediately said, Mr. Berryman, just hold the line and I'll ask Mr. Thompson where your trousers are.
Now, why he thought of me, I'll never know, but he came over and knocked at my door and he said, Mr. Thompson, have you taken Mr. Berryman's trousers?
And I said, yes, sir.
They're under the mattress, sir, in his room.
And he said, thank you, Mr. Thompson.
I thought I might as well buy a ticket back to Pennsylvania.
I'd been here about a month and I was already in trouble.
And there were several other little incidents that happened like that that sound pretty silly, but they did happen.
Isn't he delightful?
Yes, several other things have happened.
I think old Jelly Belly was the fondest term with which I am referred.
We have a lot of fun.
We have had an awful lot of fun.
I think usually when the boys play a trick on me, I laugh as hard as they do.
I think it's fun.
There were a number of, I think before we go, I'd like to tell something that wasn't funny, but it's touching.
The president of Pytos Sigma had been in the army one year.
He'd been in the army, and his tummy was pretty well damaged.
And he collapsed one day on his way home to near Temple, Texas, where they lived.
He and his wife come from there.
And she took him to Scott and White immediately, and they found that Morris was a pretty sick boy and he needed some blood.
So within two or three days came a Saturday, and two carload of Aggies went up immediately
to give blood for Mars.
The promise with which they did it and the sincerity with which they did it almost would bring tears.
We have something here at A&M.
We have a spirit of brotherhood that we don't talk about.
Aggies think it's not manly to say nice things, but our hearts are very warm.
I've seen many, many instances where people
did things for their buddies.
And I'm proud of that aspect also of our fine school.
This is a great school.
It's not an ordinary school.
Was there any other thing you need to say before we close?
No, I've enjoyed talking with you.
I would say that anybody that's had the privilege of spending a lifetime at A&M is far richer for the experience.
And I think, again, A&M is a wonderful place to work, partly because it's fun.
but more because you seriously respect yourself for being a part of this kind of a serious environment.
Period.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
And thank you very much for postponing it from Tuesday.
